nodes.body:
The secondary verb བསྡད་ “to stay” has an aspectual sense. The main verb, which is followed by བསྡད་, must take the past tense. The connective ནས་ may optionally be placed between the main verb and the secondary verb: Verb + (ནས་) བསྡད་ + Auxiliary.

The secondary verb བསྡད་ indicates that an action that was begun in the past is in the process of happening either in the present or from a past point of reference, or that the state of affairs resulting from this action is still present. The secondary verb may be followed by:

(a) perfective auxiliaries: བསྡད་པ་ཡིན་ (egophoric), བསྡད་པ་རེད་ (assertive), བསྡད་སོང་ (testimonial)

(b) perfect auxiliaries: བསྡད་ཡོད་ (egophoric), བསྡད་ཡོད་རེད་ (assertive), བསྡད་བཞག་ (inferential)

The former constructions (a) may be translated by the perfective, and the latter (b) by the imperfective or the present perfect continuous according to the context. The use of adverbs such as “still” may help to convey the meaning of these constructions.

  • རྡོ་རྗེ་ནང་ལ་ལོག་ཡོང་དུས་ཉི་མས་དེབ་བལྟས་(ནས་)བསྡད་བཞག “When Dorjé got back home, Nyima was still reading a book.”
  • ཁ་ས་ཁྲོམ་ལ་ཐུག་དུས་མོ་རང་གིས་མར་ཉོས་(ནས་)བསྡད་བཞག “Yesterday, when I met her in the market, she was buying butter.”
  • མོ་རང་ངུས་ནས་བསྡད་པ་རེད། “She’s been crying constantly.”
  • འཛིན་གྲྭའི་ནང་ལ་སྐད་ཆ་བཤད་ནས་བསྡད་པ་རེད། “He’s been talking all the time in class.”

The construction may also indicate a resulting state.

  • ཁོ་རང་ན་བསྡད་བཞག “He’s still unwell.”
  • མོ་རང་ལང་བསྡད་བཞག “She’s up.” (Literally: “She got up and she’s stayed up.” Compare this with the sentence མོ་རང་ཡར་ལངས་སོང་། “She got up.”)
